I'm pretty bad at math and I have 4 months to study various related subjects for a test, so I'm doing an excel sheet to make a schedule. I will study 6 days a week for about 2 hours a day. I was thinking of doing one subject per day and, when I practice all the subjects (there are 15), I will go back to the first one and so on.

The thing is it will take 14 days to study a given subject again and I'm afraid I'll forget what I learned on the first time. I thought of studying the same subject for two subsequent days, but the problem is still the same.

So, how should I organize this properly?

if you're motivated, you could add more study time everyday (it doesn't have to be a continuous 2 hrs), or increase your schedule to 7 days a week

the video comes from one of the top universities in the u.s. so the idea is extremely credible

but 30 minutes is the lowest you go, because otherwise it becomes like multitasking, which will hurt the learning process
the key is to make sure you keep the routine going

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
45 minutes per session then take a short break of about 10-15 minutes. Don't do anything exciting. Then you will review your previous session for a few minutes to help consolidate memory since recall peaks then, don't know why, neurons are weird, connections still being made I suppose.

Then a five minute break, or more if you like, and start next session. Three 45 minute sessions per day is 2 hours 15 minutes plus review sessions.

You can pretty much guarantee you will forget almost everything after 4 months that you started with so every week you will review the all of the previous week's work.

Less than 30 minutes is almost certainly too short. More than 50 minutes and your attention span is probably reached.

Don't eat sugar or starchy food prior to study sessions, don't want blood in your guts or hormones changing your biochemistry. Get good rest. Get physical exercise.

Because you have four months, meditate. Meditation does not produce instant results but you've got plenty of time for a daily mindfulness based meditation practice to help your test marks go up. Not the best reason to meditate but better than nothing.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>1305593
Thanks for the tips, anon. I value sleep and physical activity a lot, that's why I getting into bed at 11h30pm tops and haven't quit my judo training sessions. I thought sugar was supposed to help tho lol, I'll keep that in mind.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>1305593
And also thanks for the meditation tip, I suppose it will make me less anxious during the test?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>1305605
I don't think it's making you less anxious that helps--though that might be a good thing since I believe mindfulness based meditation can help with anxiety. Dour months might be long enough to see changes like lower anxiety in tests, though I don't know of studies that cover that aspect.

There are a whole heap of changes going on inside your brain during meditation. One of those is syncing your brain hemispheres which helps learning and study and another is activation of the frontal lobe and hippocampus which also help memory and recall. While short term, like over a week, shows benefits over months you will start making long term changes that can positively benefit much of mental and physical health.

>judo
Great stuff, lots of fun, builds character and discipline, coordinates body and mind

>11h30pm
As a practical hint, one of the best times to study is early in the morning. Lights out 10 pm, studying by 6 am. After telling some people this I did start getting up at 4am, bed before 10 pm because I needed more than 6 hours in bed, and doing my paperwork then, along with a morning run, yoga, meditation. I kept up early starts for a few years before falling into bad habits.

(The existence of "night owls" and "morning larks" as actual types of people rather than acquired behaviours is disputed so if you want to say you're a night owl that's fine, but I don't believe science supports that.)

>>1305604
>thought sugar was supposed to help

Feel free to look up the effects of insulin, which spikes after sugar intake, on memory formation, mood, and cognition. Added sugar will also decrease brain-derived neurotrophic factor which is required for new memory formation. Sugar is necessary for humans, but added sugar is bad. Eating sugar and glycogenic foods like white flour pasta, noodles, bread, cookies, etc spikes your blood sugar and don't help memories form.

>>1305117
I used to just buy whatever the fuck was on quicksale at the grocery store otw home from class and figure out a recipe based on what I had + cheap greens like scallions. Keeps your options cycling, no stagnating, no "oh this shit again". Cooking itself ain't bad, can youtube shit and try new things every week too. Leftover ingredients get chucked into a casserole / stirfry / omelette. The recipes that work I keep and reuse. There's a lot of experimentation. Cooking being a pain in the ass is also a function of the equipment you have so I mean you can get away with a college tier setup but it's so much comfier when you throw some $ at a decent dutch oven (most versatile pot), a steel wok, but the rest of it like a cheap $20 1 button rice cooker, and a walmart santoku knife don't got to splurge. Like even if it's just some simple bullshit like poaching a few eggs, grilling some chops, and adding some greens to $0.25 of pasta that's like 5min of prep and 10-15min of afk. use a phone app to keep track of ingredients to buy and then its a quick in/out at the store, no dicking around.

Like hell yeah if you can afford to eat takeout frequently (viet noodle bowls are fuckin fresh) from working so much I mean, that's also a way to cut down on your mental strain and try new shit constantly.

posts.com:
Decode this: ENT1yWWhLL-Qz9mK

A Twitter snowflake ID is a 64-bit binary number, with 41 bits representing a timestamp, 10 bits representing a machine ID, and 12 bits representing a per-machine sequence number. The snowflake ID is generally serialized in decimal format and is used in the post URL.

For example,
https://twitter.com/i/status/1581674019991916545
Decoding 1581674019991916545:
{'creation_time_milliseconds': 1665935447105,
'datacenter_id': 10,
'machine_id': 337,
'sequence_id': 1,
'server_id': 17}

The filename of a Twitter photo also contains a base64-encoded snowflake ID. This can be decoded into a regular snowflake ID, although it contains three "extra" unknown bytes.
For example,
https://pbs.twimg.com/media/FdMR2WDaMAMPt2q?format=jpg
FdMR2WDaMAMPt2q -> 1572620320212922371

It is unknown if the filename of a Twitter video also contains a snowflake ID. You can see the URL contains it, but any off-platform video would would only contain the file name.
For example,
https://video.twimg.com/ext_tw_video/1564378065198882816/pu/vid/960x720/ENT1yWWhLL-Qz9mK.mp4

How would "ENT1yWWhLL-Qz9mK" be decoded into a snowflake, if it's possible?

Resources:
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Snowflake_ID
https://discord.com/developers/docs/reference#snowflakes (good visualizations, twitter uses another epoch)
https://docs.google.com/document/d/1xVrPoNutyqTdQ04DXBEZW4ZW4A5RAQW2he7qIpTmG-M/edit

Toilet valves are vaguely standardised (they're standardised in britain, but they're vaguely-standardised everywhere).

You just need a new diaphragm in your valve. The bit that's leaking unscrews so's you can get it. Find out how to turn the water off, then unscrew the thing that looks like a bottle cap next to the bit you circled. It will lift off and a rubber diaphragm will be underneath it. Most hardware stores, and even a bunch of dollar stores will have a "toilet repair kit" that will include one of them. Just swap it with a new one then screw it back together, and voila, you have repaired a toilet and gained 2.71 masculinity points.

The feeding tube is a rigid plastic tube poiting down right where you can see that hole.
The part where water comes out is a lever. When flushing the water level falls, this makes the swimmer come down wihich pulls the lever and opens the valve, the water then flows down the tube which rarises the level and through its bouyancy pushes the swimmer back up which makes the lever close the valve.
The part where OP has water coming out of is the lever's hinge, it should not come out there. Which means it's no longer water proof in opened state. As OP mentioned at the moment it still is when closed, but that will just be a matter of time. The part should be replaced. Either the whole thing or the diaphragm if after all those years it can actually still be opened.

>>1304897
Okay, first thing to do is calm down and don't force anything or do anything dumb.

Toilets aren't very complicated machines, so you just need to walk through each step in the turning-off process and make sure it works:
- the float floats to the top of the tank: make sure it's free to move up and down
- the float pushes on an arm that pushes the diaphragm against the inlet: make sure the arm's connected at both ends, and moving the float moves the arm
- the diaphragm blocks the water: make sure it's sealing across the inlet properly. You said the previous diaphragm fell apart, so it's probably a good idea to look inside the bit where it was and make sure there's no bits left behind stopping the new diaphragm from seating properly

If you have a screwdriver, follow the pipe entering the toilet. There's probably going to be one of these on it, turn it gently 90 degrees to turn off just that toilet.

>>1305110
Yeah even what appears to be the chorus line "In the heat of the night" has absolutely nothing on any lyric site. Now granted, lyric websites aren't really reliable for pre-1980's songs that aren't pop, but this *sounds* like a very competent band in a high-quality studio recording, so it should probably be searchable on the internet.

I've listened to this multiple times now and I'm convinced it's an "industry" song. The guitar sounds like CCR, and the vocalist sounds like Allan Clarke in "Long Cool Woman in a Black Dress", but despite being pretty familiar with 60's-70's rock I have absolutely no idea who plays this song. The song plays for the whole 2 minutes in the scene, which is far beyond the free-use limit of any copyrighted song. Combine that with this episode not having any song credits, which it would absolutely need to have if this song was owned. I think what we have is a royalty-free song by a working studio band/group for television and film, and when given the criteria "make something country-rock for bar scenes", they made a surprisingly good tune that should have been from a real band.

Yes. Never accept any pending/reallocated sectors.

What you can do is image it onto a new disk, slow format it (to write to every sector), and then all the pending sectors will turn into reallocated ones, and you can use if for data that doesn't matter, like as an external drive for a console, or your steam downloads.

>>1305519

50/50 in the next month

Useage of reallocated sectors is the like THE most urgent indicator of coming failure.
BUT it's still just an indicator. Latge HDD tests by google had as result that after the first reallocated sectors IF it failed it was during the following month, if it survived that month the probability of failure sunk again to its normal value as if that reallocation never happened.
So: NEVER assume a disk with this error as safe, if it has important stuff backup immediately!
COnsider everything on it volatile and possibly gone any minute now.
BUT it's not necessarily dead, Jim. You can continue using it as non-critical storage, stuff that would not be a big deal if lost, where it may continue to work for years to come.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>1305579
>That 1 could also mean your HDD is about to die.
FFS, if you don't know how to interpret what you're looking at, have you considered just not posting?

For anything in the current/worst/threshold columns, you treat it as an abstract number that represents the drive's opinion on how fucked it is.
- worst below threshold: drive failed at some time in the past (in the opinion of the drive's firmware)
- current below threshold: drive is failing now (in the opinion of the drive's firmware)
In the case of the one you're upset about, 1>0, and 1>0, so (in the opinion of the drive's firmware) the drive isn't failing that category now, and hasn't failed it in the past. That's literally all you're allowed to infer from those columns, they don't represent anything specific, just an abstract number of "not-fucked points".

As >>1305575 rightly points out, the killer here is "reallocated sector count". For this column, ignore the firmware's opinion on how many are acceptable: zero are acceptable. Look in "raw value", if it's anything other than zero, or "pending sectors" is anything other than zero, the drive is no-longer reliable and could die at any moment. Or something absolutely vital like your bitcoin wallet or the key block of your encrypted disk image could spontaneously turn into a pending sector.
>Man, these GUI tools. I swear...
It's the exact same table you get from smartctl. Bad workman blames his tools.
>>1305575
don't forget pending sectors, a pending sector is just a reallocated sector that hasn't been reallocated yet because nothing has overwritten it.

Soil.

Don't look ANYTHING up about it, this is the one manga you should have NOTHING spoiled about for you going in. Don't even read a fucking synopsis or the MAL page, don't even look up genres, go in COMPLETELY blind.
There's certain pieces of media that Soil makes reference to or that it draws inspiration from, but nothing is necessary to know going into it. If you're already familiar with the media it references or draws inspiration from, it'll give you a couple "Oh, cute" moments but that's really it.

Soil is an extremely high quality manga with an artstyle that quite deliberately strays from conventional manga art. Some people dislike the style, I love it.

After you've read Soil, if you enjoyed it you should check out everything else that mangaka did. Soil is actually pretty tame in terms of being "mindfuck" compared to some of the other shit he did.

>>1302968
I like the quote. Thanks for posting it.

The problem I'm seeing is that you're mixing up different paradigms. Looking for empirical evidence of a miracle means treating it as a natural phenomenon, i.e. something that you could be wrong about and therefore need to gather and examine evidence for. But the paradigm of faith is the opposite of this. In faith, you begin with your conclusion, and intentionally pass over the rest.

The fact that you perceive *any* value in empirical evidence means you actually aren't thinking in terms of faith in the first place. So, no amount of empirical evidence is going to help. Even if you did find a video of a miracle happening, it would be better for you to not watch it. There's nothing new that it could teach you, but there is some risk that examining a piece of empirical evidence (e.g. a video recording) could end up leading you into changing your mind.

There's nothing to be gained. You are already complete and perfect. Trust in the Lord your God. If you look back, you will become a salt pillar.

>>1305571

They need a new IP. For that they will have to reconnect the last entry point before the wire. If that last point is a router thy will either have issue a reconnect/reset from its menu or simply momentarily remove power from it.
If they use WLAN and each of them has his own device accessing the network just restorting the device won't help since the IP is provided by the access point which all devices connect to. That access point - usually a router or one of those boxes from your ISP - has to be restarted to get a new one.

>>1304921
>How the hell do I reset a BIOS password on a crappy laptop?
Normally, for the cheap units, pulling the CMOS battery AND the main battery AND waiting 15 minutes for the tantalum to lose its charge worked. The better units may store the password on EEPROM for improved security against theft from a business or school.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>1304952
Gotcha, that seems likely. Thanks.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>1304926
>Never had anything retain after unplugging the battery,
The whole battery thing is a scam, settings have been kept in flash for decades now. What actually happens when you remove the battery is:
- RT Clock gets no power and loses time
- Next time you boot, the BIOS notices the time is gobbledygook, and copies default settings over the settings in the flash
- This is why the manuals now tell you not to remove the battery but instead keep the PC connected to standby power and jump a "clear CMOS" jumper: this instructs the SMC to overwrite the settings
So obviously, whether the BIOS password gets deleted or not is up to the BIOS. Most desktop boards will (though some have a separate jumper for clearing the password), most laptop boards won't. On most laptops, you have to interfere with the flash chip the settings are on while it's trying to read it, then the BIOS will conclude the settings are gobbledygook and overwrite all of them, including the password, or at least won't be able to read a valid password so it won't ask you for one this boot and then you can remove your interference and set your own password. And then on some laptops it's simply not possible because they read an activation record that comes from the internet, for example recent macbooks that are enrolled in device management or find-my-iphone.

Download binary from https://github.com/ggerganov/whisper.cpp/actions/runs/3876737052 (you will need to login to github to be able to download it)
then download the model from https://huggingface.co/datasets/ggerganov/whisper.cpp depending on your needs (how well it should work and whether you need just english or other languages too) and hardware specs (how much disk space and memory you want to use for it). base.en would be probably reasonable start
then in commandline from directory where you have the binary run
<name_of_the_binary> -m <path_to_downloaded_model,_probably_base.en> -f <path_to_file_you_want_to_transcribe>
you would substitute contents of <...> for actual values
Also the file it will transcribe needs to be .wav, so you might need to convert it first if it's in different format

Photopea.com
Drag in all of your images or use file > open
Drag two layers until they're lined up and use arrow keys to fine tune

played super smash bros and punch-out

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>1304853
Depends what you want out of the games. Plot-wise, you start with production order. The series is fairly linear in that regard, except Wild Ambition which is a remake of the first game that no one really cares. Competitive-wise, Fatal Fury Special, Real Bout FF Special, RBFF2 and Garou: Mark of the Wolves are the most played, in ascending order. The RB games are fairly similar but different balances and play a little bit like Street Fighter Alpha 2; FFS is kinda like Street Fighter 2; Garou: MotW is kinda like 3rd Strike but not really (also, largely different roster from the rest of the series and removed a bunch of mechanics from previous games, making it the most SF-like of the series.) Also, make sure to check out the KOF series and Capcom vs SNK 2. Terry and his friends are mainstays in these games.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>1305130
No, I don't keep hearing any frequency afterwards, it's more like everything starts to sound weird, but like I said it goes away pretty quickly. I do play around with synths quite a bit and I've had this happen a few times, but I've noticed it doesn't happen at all if I put a low pass filter on it, so I suspect it has something to do with the high harmonic content of the saw wave and similar waveshapes.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>1305137
From what I know the low frequencies and the high frequencies can be pretty harmful. Use limiters on your master channel, avoid headphones, set master volume to be at normal speaking level, try adding filters like a LP / HP like you just mentioned. Saw waves reese bass will make your ears bleed. As far as the distortion, that could be the source of it, or it could be something else entirely, but the synths need to be muzzled or you'll go deaf before you know it.
